Graphical Abstract Here we report the relationships between the structure of the vanadia species, acid-base, and redox properties of the surface of tailor-made monolayer MgVOx/Al2O3 catalysts and the effects of these features on the performance of such catalysts. Combined Raman and UV-vis DR spectroscopies confirmed the formation of the alumina-supported 2D surface VOx and MgVOx species with different coordination and local environment of the active site. The Mg incorporation into the structure of the surface vanadia species was shown to affect both their redox and acid properties and allows controlling the catalyst activity and selectivity towards propylene. Increasing the binding energy of V–O bonds due to Mg doping was shown to be critical to improve the catalyst performance but is not the only factor determining high selectivity towards propylene that is also affected by the concentration of strong acid sites and surface species structure. Keywords propane oxidative dehydrogenation propylene selectivity monolayer vanadia catalyst surface magnesium vanadate structure-performance relationship 1 Introduction Recent and ongoing growth of the polypropylene market results in a gap between the demand and supply of propylene [1-3]. This stimulates the development of on-purpose technologies for propylene manufacturing. Oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane is a promising way of propylene production that has gained global attention due to favorable thermodynamics and enhanced catalyst stability in contrast to the current nonoxidative dehydrogenation technology [2-4]. However, low process selectivity due to rapid consecutive propylene overoxidation remains a challenge for its industrial implementation [5,6]. The supported vanadia catalysts are among the most promising candidates for ODH of light alkanes [3,7,8]. Vanadium in surface vanadia species is believed to be the active site of such catalysts. The hydrocarbon transformations over vanadia catalysts follow a Mars–van Krevelen mechanism that includes rate-determining hydrocarbon oxidation followed by fast surface reoxidation by oxygen [8]. However, both propane and propylene activation proceed over the same sites, with propylene readsorption resulting in unfavorable COx formation even at moderate (8-12 %) propane conversion [8]. To improve the catalyst selectivity, different approaches to catalyst design, reactor and process operation mode have been suggested [4,5]. The idea to regulate the properties of the vanadium oxide catalyst by changing the redox potential of vanadia species via the formation of V–O–M bonds (M = Al, Si, Ti, Zr, Mo, Mg, Zr, etc.) has been repeatedly discussed [2,5,7–12]. The vanadia–support systems are primarily considered, with the support playing an important role in controlling the catalyst activity and selectivity [7]. Several supports were applied, namely, γ- and θ-alumina and silica [8,13], ordered silica-based materials (SBA-15 [14], MCM-41 [15], etc.), SiC [16], titania [8,13], bare zirconia and its mixture with ceria [8,13,17], zeolites [18], etc. The cations of the oxide support are believed to act as ligands in the second coordination sphere of vanadium changing the redox potential of the surface vanadia species and thereby the catalyst reactivity towards both ODH of propane and subsequent propylene oxidation. As a result, for the most studied supports, the activity of vanadia catalysts decreases in a row ZrO2 > TiO2 > Al2O3 > SiO2, with the selectivity changing inversely [8]. Besides, for all supports, a strong dependence of catalyst performance on the structure of vanadia species has been reported, with the isolated vanadia species being considered the key factor to obtain high selectivity [2,5,8]. The oligomerized and polymerized vanadia species were shown to be less selective. However, due to the lack of kinetic control, a purposeful increase of the selectivity of supported vanadia catalysts only due to the changing of the support nature is unachievable. To further improve the selectivity of such a catalyst, the tailor-made design of supported vanadia catalysts modified with different dopants is required. A number of publications [19–24] elucidated the effects of dopants (Mg, Ca, K, Na) that tune the acid-base properties of the catalyst surface and reported exclusively the consequences that such modification had on the overall catalyst reactivity. However, the dopant effects on the dispersion or structure of vanadia species, and the structure–reactivity relationships between the surface structure of the modified composites and the response to the catalytic activity remain poorly discussed [25]. Recent publications are devoted to the effect of alkaline and alkaline-earth dopants on the structure of vanadia species in conjunction with the catalytic activity data [2,9,26–28]. Thus, Herman’s group reported the promoting effect of sodium on silica support to enhance the 2D dispersion of vanadia species [2,26]. This proportionally increased the rate of propane ODH while keeping high propylene selectivity. The Na+ cations were suggested to participate in ion exchange with surface silanols to form more reactive Si − O–Na+ anchoring sites. In our previous studies, the effect of modification of alumina-supported vanadia catalyst by MgO was considered [9,27]. The modification of vanadia catalyst with magnesia was shown to be accompanied by a change in the composition and structure of the surface vanadia species due to the formation of surface magnesium vanadates. These changes affected the redox potential of the species decreasing the catalytic activity, but increasing the selectivity towards propylene. However, the key factor determining the performance of MgVOx/Al2O3 catalyst remains poorly understood. Besides, the materials with vanadia surface density of only ∼0.5 monolayer were investigated due to restriction arising from using ammonium metavanadate water solution for catalyst preparation. This could affect the structure and composition of the formed surface magnesium vanadates due to the low degree of aggregation of vanadia species, the formation of microcrystalline V2O5 as well as the modifier–support interaction. Here we present the new insights on the tailor-made 2D monolayer MgVOx/Al2O3 materials with the emphasis on the relationships between the structures of the vanadia species, acid-base characteristics, and redox properties of the catalyst surface and their response to the catalyst performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The samples were prepared according to the previously proposed technique [9]. It was shown that consecutive impregnation of Al2O3, including impregnation with V precursor solution followed by intermediate calcination at 500 °C to form polymeric VOx species on the support surface at the first stage and subsequent impregnation with Mg precursor, allows the formation of surface MgVOx species. However, using the ammonium metavanadate water solution for vanadia deposition did not allow obtaining the samples with high vanadia surface density and also resulted in the formation of microcrystalline V2O5 as an impurity phase in the unmodified V2O5/Al2O3 sample even for the surface density of ∼0.5 monolayer. The subsequent modification of such a sample by magnesia did not result in the disappearance of crystalline V2O5. In the present study, a monolayer V2O5/Al2O3 sample (defined as VOx/Al) was prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation of alumina support (AOK 63-22/K, JSC “Katalizator”, Russia; specific surface area was 134  m2/g; water capacity was 0.87 ml/g) with an aqueous solution of ammonium vanadyl oxalate [29]. The amount of vanadium in the sample was calculated per monolayer surface coating with vanadia species based on the assumption of 9 V atoms/nm2 of support [8]. To avoid the formation of crystalline V2O5 along with the 2D vanadia species, the VOx/Al sample was prepared using acidic (pH < 2) water solution of ammonium vanadyl oxalate. Under these conditions, the surface hydroxyl groups of the alumina characterized by the isoelectric point IEP = 8.5 [9] are protonated: (1) S–OH + H+ → (S–OH2)+. This promotes the sorption of [VO(C2O4)2]2- complex on the positively charged support accompanied by a ligand substitution reactions including the exchange of ligands of the vanadyl complex by functional groups of the support oxide (2) or interaction with the support via an ion exchange reaction (3) [29,31]: (2) x(S–OH2)+ + [VO(C2O4)2]2- → (S–O)xVO(C2O4)2-x + xH2C2O4, (3) 2(S–OH2)+ + [VO(C2O4)2]2- → (S–cation)2[VO(C2O4)2] + 2H2O. In this case, the subsequent drying and calcination of the sample do not significantly affect the vanadia dispersion and surface distribution providing the formation of the alumina-supported 2D vanadia species with high surface density. To prepare the impregnating solution, NH4VO3 (Acros Organics, 99.0%) and oxalic acid (VEKTON, 99.0%) were used as a source of vanadium and as a reducing and complexing agent, respectively. NH4VO3 and oxalic acid were dissolved in distilled water in the NH4VO3:H2C2O4 molar ratio of 1:2.5 followed by solution heating at 80 °C. The blue solution was finally obtained due to the formation of [VO(C2O4)2]2- complex ions (4) stable in the acidic pH range [30,31]: (4) 2NH4VO3 + 5H2C2O4 ↔ 2(NH4)H[VO(C2O4)2] + 2CO2 + 4H2O. The impregnated sample was dried at 120 °C and then calcined at 500 °C. The MgO–V2O5/Al2O3 samples with different Mg/V molar ratios (defined as MgVOx/Al(0.4), MgVOx/Al(0.8), MgVOx/Al(1.1), MgVOx/Al(1.7), MgVOx/Al(4.0), Table 1 ) were prepared by the subsequent impregnation of the VOx/Al sample with the aqueous solution of magnesium nitrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, VEKTON, 99.0%). All samples were dried at 120 °C and then calcined in air at 500 °C. Such a procedure provided sorption of Mg2+ ions on the surface vanadia species of the monolayer VOx/Al sample during the impregnation step leading to the surface magnesium vanadates after the sample calcination [9]. 2.2 Catalyst Characterization The samples prepared were studied using a complex of methods, including low-temperature nitrogen sorption, X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV-vis and Raman spectroscopies, and temperature-programmed reduction methods. The results presented concern fresh samples before the catalytic test. The textural characteristics of the samples were studied by low-temperature nitrogen sorption using a TriStar II 3020 analyzer (Micromeritics, USA). Prior to the experiments, the samples were degassed at 200 °C in a vacuum (10–2 Torr) for 2 h using VacPrep Degasser (Micromeritics, USA). Specific surface area (SSA) was determined using the BET method, while the pore size distribution was calculated using the BJH method from the desorption branch of the adsorption-desorption isotherm. The chemical composition of the samples was analyzed on the sequential X-ray fluorescence spectrometer XRF-1800 (Shimadzu, Japan). The phase composition and structural characteristics of the samples were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV-vis and Raman spectroscopies. The XRD patterns of the samples were taken using a MiniFlex 600 diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) with a monochromatic CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The phase composition of the samples was determined using PDF-4 (Release 2011) and PDF-2 (Release 2012 RDB) databases. UV-vis spectra of the samples were obtained with a spectrophotometer Cary100 (Varian, Australia) in a diffuse reflection (DR) mode using the DRA-CA-30I accessory (Labsphere, USA) in the wavelength range of 300–800 nm. MgO was used as a reference sample. To obtain the spectra of the dehydrated samples, the materials were treated at 200 °C for 2 h in air and then for 1.5 min in a vacuum (10–2 Torr) in special hermetically sealed reactors with a valve using the VacPrep Degasser (Micromeritics, USA). The reflection spectra were transformed into the absorption spectra using the Kubelka–Munk function: F(R) = (1 – R)2/(2R), where R is the reflection factor. The edge energy (Eg) was determined from the UV-Vis spectra using the Davis-Mott equation: [F(R)·hν] ∝ (hν·Eg)n, where F(R) are Kubelka-Munk units, h is a Planck constant, ν is a wavenumber, n = 1/2 and 2 for allowed direct and indirect transitions, respectively. Raman spectra were taken using the InVia spectrometer (Renishaw, UK) equipped with the DM 2500 M microscope (Leica, Germany) with a 50x objective. The laser with a power of 100 mW and a wavelength of 785 nm was used, with a spectral resolution being 1 cm-1. The spectral range of 100–1200 cm-1 was considered. To prevent changes in the samples, only 5% of the total laser power and beam defocusing of 50% were used. The signal of a single spectrum was accumulated during 1 sec, and the number of scans was up to 200. To take the Raman spectra of the dehydrated samples, the online sample dehydration was carried out using 100% of the total laser power. The reducibility of the samples was studied by temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (TPR-H2) using a chemisorption analyzer ChemiSorb 2750 (Micromeritics, USA) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to the experiments, the samples were treated in air flow (20 cm3/min) in the TPR mode up to 500 °C followed by dwelling at 500 °C for 30 min and cooling down to room temperature. The TPR-H2 experiments were carried out from room temperature to up to 900 °C using a mixture of 10 vol.% H2 in Ar with a flow rate of 20 cm3/min and a heating rate of 10 deg/min. To avoid the effect of water formed, a cold trap (ca. −90 °C) was set prior to the detector. The acid properties of the samples were studied by TPD-NH3 and pulsed NH3 adsorption. The TPD-NH3 experiments were carried out using the chemisorption analyzer ChemiSorb 2750 (Micromeritics, USA) in a U-shaped quartz reactor coupled with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (MS) UGA 300 (Stanford Research Systems, USA). Before the experiments, the sample (∼0.06–0.13 g corresponding to the sample surface of 8.3 m2) were treated in air flow (20 cm3/min) in a TPR mode up to 500 °C followed by dwelling at 500 °C for 30 min and cooling down to 75 °C. The air flow was switched to He flow (20 cm3/min) to remove air and then to the one with a mixture of 10% NH3 in He (20 cm3/min). The sample was treated at 75 °C in the mixture of NH3 in He for 1 h to chemosorb NH3 and then in He (20 cm3/min) to remove physically adsorbed NH3. After that, the TPD-NH3 in He flow (20 cm3/min) was carried out from 75 to up to 600 °C using a heating rate of 10 deg/min. The desorption of NH3 and H2O was monitored using the MS data (m/z = 16, 17, and 18). NH3 pulse adsorption was used to determine the amount of surface acid sites. The experiments were carried out using an AutoChem 2950 HP analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) equipped with a TCD and a reactor coupled with the quadrupole MS UGA 300 (Stanford Research Systems, USA). Prior to the NH3 pulse adsorption, the samples (∼0.02–0.03 g) were treated in air flow (20 cm3/min) in a TPR mode up to 500 °C followed by dwelling at 500 °C for 30 min. After the sample cooling down to 100 °C (to determine the total amount of the surface acid sites) or 250 °C (to determine the fraction of strong acid sites) in air, the flow was switched to He (30 cm3/min) used as a carrier gas. Then the pulses (0.5 mL) of the mixture of 10% NH3 in He were periodically injected until the constant TCD and MS (m/z = 16, 17, and 18) peak areas. The amount of the NH3 adsorbed was determined from the TCD and MS data according to the calibration. C3H6 pulse adsorption was used to study the propylene adsorption. The experiments were carried out using the AutoChem 2950 HP analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) equipped with the TCD and a reactor coupled with the quadrupole MS UGA 300 (Stanford Research Systems, USA). Before the experiments, the samples were treated in air flow (20 cm3/min) in a TPR mode to up to 500 °C followed by dwelling at 500 °C for 30 min and cooling down to 425 °C. Then the flow was switched to He (30 cm3/min) used as a carrier gas. Pulses (0.5 mL) of the mixture of 10% C3H6 in N2 were periodically injected, with the composition of the flow being monitored with the MS (m/z = 41, 39, 44, 28 and 18). 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic properties of the samples were examined in the ODH of propane at 400–500 °C and atmospheric pressure in a flow catalytic unit with a fixed bed tubular reactor and an online analysis of products. The reactor represented a quartz tube (i.d. of 10 mm) equipped with a coaxial thermocouple for temperature profiling. A gas mixture of 5% C3H8 and 5% O2 diluted by N2 was used as a feed. Flow rates of the reactant mixture were varied from 6.0 to 13.5 l/h to provide different contact times. Typically, 0.02-0.09 g of a sample (particle sizes were between 0.25 and 0.5 mm, bulk volume was 1.0–1.2 cm3/g) placed into the reactor were diluted with a 1 cm3 of quartz (particle sizes between 0.5 and 1 mm) in order to minimize the temperature gradients. The sample was treated in the flow of air at 500 °C for 30 min prior to the reaction. Blank studies using an empty reactor showed that homogeneous reactions could be neglected under the experimental conditions used in the present work. To analyze the reaction products, Chromatec-Crystal 5000.2 (Chromatec, Russia) gas chromatograph equipped with methanizer, TCD and FID detectors was used. NaX and PoraPlot Q columns were utilized to separate the reaction products. Propane conversions, X(C2H8), propylene selectivity, S(C3H6), and carbon balance, B, were calculated as follows: X ( C 3 H 8 ) = 3 C C 3 H 6 + 2 C C 2 H 4 + 2 C C 2 H 6 + C C O 2 + C C O 3 C C 3 H 8 + 3 C C 3 H 6 + 2 C C 2 H 4 + 2 C C 2 H 6 + C C O 2 + C C O ⋅ 100 % S ( C 3 H 8 ) = 3 C C 3 H 6 3 C C 3 H 6 + 2 C C 2 H 4 + 2 C C 2 H 6 + C C O 2 + C C O ⋅ 100 % B = 3 C C 3 H 8 + 3 C C 3 H 6 + 2 C C 2 H 4 + 2 C C 2 H 6 + C C O 2 + C C O 3 C C 3 H 8 o ⋅ v out . v i n ⋅ 100 % where CC3H8 and CO2 are the concentrations of reagents in the outlet flow (vol.%); CC3H6, CC2H6, CC2H4, CCO2, and CCO are concentrations of the products in the outlet flow (vol.%); C°C3H8 is the concentration of reagents in the feed gas (vol.%); v in and v out are inlet and outlet gas flow rates (ml∙min-1), respectively. In all experiments, carbon balance was 98–100% that is in agreement with the gas chromatography analytical error. The apparent activation energy of the propane transformation over the catalysts was determined from the temperature dependence of the initial reaction rate at 450–500 °C using Arrhenius plots. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Composition and textural characteristics of the samples Table 1 presents the chemical composition and textural characteristics of the prepared samples. The vanadium content in the VOx/Al sample corresponds to the theoretical monolayer coverage (9 V atoms/nm2) [8], while the magnesium amount in the MgVOx/Al samples varies within the range of Mg/V molar ratios from 0.4 to 4.0. A decrease in specific surface area and pore volume is observed for all samples as compared with the bare alumina support. The changes observed in the textural characteristics for the VOx/Al sample indicate a uniform distribution of the vanadia in the porous space of the support, with support surface near the contact of the particles being occluded during the temperature treatment at 500 °C (for details see Supplementary Information). The observed changes in the textural characteristics of MgVOx/Al(0.4), MgVOx/Al(0.8), MgVOx/Al(1.1), and MgVOx/Al(1.7) samples primarily occurred due to the mass increase in the course of the VOx/Al sample modification with MgO and generally corresponded to a uniform modifier distribution over the surface. However, further increase of the Mg content results in a dramatic change of the textural characteristics of the MgVOx/Al(4.0) sample indicating a nonuniform distribution of the supported components in the porous space of the support. This could be due to the filling and blocking of the support pores by MgO that simultaneously contributes to the formation of the texture of the sample (for details see Supplementary Information). The XRD patterns of the samples are characterized by the presence of wide reflections of the alumina support phases, namely, γ- and θ-Al2O3 (Fig. 1 ). The XRD data do not reveal the formation of the crystalline V2O5, magnesium oxide or magnesium vanadates in the samples with the Mg/V molar ratio up to 1.7. MgO phase exists only in the MgVOx/Al(4.0) sample with the Mg excess, while no crystalline V2O5 or magnesium vanadates are detected. This indicates a high dispersion of the supported vanadia phases formed in all samples. To study the state of vanadium and the specific features of the real structure of such dispersed phases, the UV-vis DR and Raman spectroscopies that are sensitive to the local environment of the atoms in the structures of crystalline, amorphous, and surface (including two-dimensional) phases were used for both hydrated and dehydrated samples [29]. 3.2 UV-Vis spectroscopy Fig. 2 represents the UV-vis spectra for the prepared samples. All spectra show the intense absorption below 600 nm due to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transitions of V(V) [32,33]. A weak absorption attributed to the d–d transitions of V(IV) in structures with V = O group [32,34] is additionally presented in the region of 600–850 nm in the spectra of the VOx/Al and MgVOx/Al(0.4) samples indicating the presence of a noticeable amount of V(IV) in them, especially in the unmodified VOx/Al sample. The ambient spectrum of the VOx/Al sample is characterized by the LMCT transitions of V(V) in the range of 300–550 nm with the intense absorption at ∼400–450 nm typical for V(V) in a square-pyramidal or distorted octahedral oxygen environment [9,27]. The edge energy (Eg) derived for the VOx/Al sample is 2.45 eV (Table 2 ). The MgO addition results in the noticeable blue shift of the absorption of LMCT transitions of V(V) cation in the corresponding ambient spectra. The edge energies derived for the MgO-modified samples increase as the Mg/V molar ratio increases (Table 2). The edge energy of the LMCT transitions of V(V) cations was shown to correlate with the coordination of V(V) cation and the number of the covalent V–O–V bonds around the central V(V) cation (CVB) [35]. According to this correlation, the changes observed in the UV-vis DR spectra of the VOx/Al and MgVOx/Al samples indicate the formation of vanadia species with a different number of covalent V–O–V bonds (Fig. 3 ). Gao and Wachs [35] proposed that the CVB number represents the degree of aggregation/polymerization of the absorbing species. However, the CVB number is also affected by vanadium coordination and the way of connection of vanadia polyhedra that is critical for supported samples with a high vanadia surface density like in the samples studied. The surface density of vanadia (that is a number of vanadium atoms per unit of the support surface) in the studied samples corresponds to the one in the VOx/Al sample, and the sample modification with Mg does not decrease the parameter. In general, it is difficult to say about the degree of aggregation/polymerization (that is a number of monomeric units in polymer or oligomer species) in such samples. Only for the CVB numbers of 1 and 0 it is possible to definitely say about the isolated dimeric and monomeric species, respectively. In our case, only for the sample with the Mg excess (Mg/V ratio of 4.0), the formation of the magnesium divanadate was confirmed by Raman spectroscopy, while the polymerized species up to the Mg/V ratio of 1.7 was indicated by a set of UV-vis spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy data (see section 3.3). At the same time, the CVB number for the supported samples with the high vanadia surface density also represents the packing density of vanadia polyhedrons in a monolayer depending on the coordination and nature of ligands in the second coordination sphere of the central V(V) cation and indicating in our case the changing in the structure of the surface MgVOx species with the increase of Mg/V ratio. Specifically, the edge energy observed for the VOx/Al sample corresponds to the V(V) cations in the surface polymerized VO5/VO6 species. The change of the edge energy from 2.45 to 2.83 eV with the increase of the Mg/V molar ratio from 0 to 1.1 is attributed to the changes in coordination environment of vanadium in polymerized vanadia species from VO5/VO6 to VO5 and VO4/VO5 units caused by Mg2+ incorporation into the second coordination sphere of vanadium. A subsequent change of the edge energy with the increase of the Mg/V molar ratio indicates the primary formation of VO4 units accompanied by a decrease in the number of covalent V–O–V bonds in the species. The dehydration of the VOx/Al sample and MgVOx/Al samples with low Mg content results in the additional blueshift of the absorption peak in the UV-vis spectra. This is accompanied by the strong increase of the absorption caused by the d–d transition of V(IV) for the VOx/Al sample indicating the reduction of some V(V) under thermal treatment in a vacuum (for details see section 2). However, the dehydration of the MgVOx/Al samples with high Mg content does not affect the spectra. Table 2 shows the corresponding edge energies derived for the dehydrated samples. The observed changes upon hydration/dehydration for VOx/Al, MgVOx/Al(0.4), and MgVOx/Al(0.8) samples are caused by the changing of the V(V) coordination in the polymerized VOx species from predominantly VO5/VO6 to VO4/VO5 [35]. This indicates the formation of supported vanadia phases in these samples as surface two-dimensional monolayer VOx and MgVOx species. The increase of the Mg content seems to result in the stabilization of the structure of such two-dimensional phases due to the formation of the 3D dispersed magnesium vanadates. However, the edge energies derived for these samples do not correspond to those of crystalline magnesium vanadates (for details see Supplementary Information). 3.3 Raman spectroscopy Fig. 4 shows the Raman spectra of the ambient and dehydrated samples (the spectrum of the alumina support does not contain the bands and is not shown for brevity). These data provide additional information on the composition and structure of the surface phases formed. In particular, they confirm the absence of the microcrystalline V2O5 phase (the typical vibrational bands at 993, 703, 527, 483, 476, 405, 305, 285, 198, and 147 cm-1 are absent [36]) in all samples prepared. In general, the Raman spectra of the samples can be divided into two groups. The first one includes the spectra of the VOx/Al, MgVOx/Al(0.4), and MgVOx/Al(0.8) samples that are changed upon the sample dehydration, while the second group comprises those of the samples with higher magnesium content identical for both hydrated and dehydrated samples. The Raman spectra of the samples from the first group are rather similar, especially in the range of 150–600 cm-1, with the magnesia addition resulting in some spectra alteration primarily in the range of 600–1100 cm-1 (for details see Supplementary Information). The sensitivity of the spectra of the samples from the first group to hydration/dehydration additionally confirms the formation of 2D phases in the corresponding samples. Besides, the similarity of the spectra of the VOx/Al, MgVOx/Al(0.4), and MgVOx/Al(0.8) samples in the range of 150–600 cm-1 indicates the relationship between the structures of vanadia species, with the difference in the range of 600–1000 cm-1 indicating the sensibility of the structure to the magnesium presence. Indeed, in solids, the vibrations of the complex anions characterized by the bonding forces inside these anions considerably exceeding those with the cation sublattice are known to be sensitive to isomorphic substitutions in the cationic positions [37]. Such substitutions affect the position of the vibration bands of the complex anions. Detailed analysis of the Raman data (see Supplementary Information) shows that the ambient Raman spectra of the VOx/Al, MgVOx/Al(0.4) and MgVOx/Al(0.8) samples reflect the formation of polymer vanadia species as a two-dimensional [(V2O6)2-]n layer formed by the chains of the edge-connected vanadium oxygen octahedra as in the metavanadates of divalent cations [38–40], with different counterions (Al3+ of the support, H+ and Mg2+ ions) stabilizing this layer. The changes observed in the spectra with the increase of magnesium content in the samples of the first group including a decrease of the intensity of the band at 996 cm-1 and appearance of the one at 952 cm-1 assigned to V = O stretching modes in VO6 are associated with the changes in the composition of cations stabilizing the surface metavanadate structures due to the magnesium introduction into the sample accompanied by the decrease in the number of protons stabilizing the surface metavanadate structure (for details see Supplementary Information). In accordance with the UV-vis DR spectroscopy data, the change in the Raman spectra of the MgVOx/Al(0.4), and MgVOx/Al(0.8) samples due to the sample dehydration suggests that a part of the vanadia polyhedra in the surface structures remains available for the interaction with water molecules. The changes in the spectra of the VOx/Al, MgVOx/Al(0.4), and MgVOx/Al(0.8) samples observed due to the sample dehydration indicate the restructuring of the surface vanadia species and are associated with the changes in the V coordination from octahedral to tetrahedral [41–43]. Thereby the Raman spectrum observed for the dehydrated VOx/Al sample was attributed to the surface 2D polymer vanadia species primarily formed by interconnected VO4 tetrahedra similar to [(VO3)-]n layers formed by VO4 tetrahedra coupled by common vertices in the structures of the monovalent cation metavanadates MeVO3 (Me = Na+, K+, Rb+, Cs+, and NH4 +) [44–46] (for details see Supplementary Information). The spectroscopic differences observed as compared with crystalline metavanadates is caused by the strong angular distortion of the vanadate tetrahedron in the surface metavanadate species. The difference in the range of 600–1000 cm-1 in the spectra of the dehydrated VOx/Al, MgVOx/Al(0.4), and MgVOx/Al(0.8) samples consisting in some alteration of the band positions and intensities reflects the magnesium effect on the structure of [(VO3)-]n in the surface polymer VOx species. The Raman data of the samples from the second group additionally confirm that further increase in the Mg/V ratio leads to the formation of vanadia species, with the structure being independent on the hydration-dehydration condition due to the stabilization by Mg2+ and Al3+ cations. However, Raman spectra of the MgVOx/Al(1.1) and MgVOx/Al(1.7) samples could not be explained by the formation of the crystalline magnesium vanadates (see Supplementary Information), but rather by the formation of the surface vanadia species formed by a combination of VO5 and VO4 polyhedra similar to [V5O14]n layers in the A3V5O14 vanadate series (A = K, Rb, and Tl) [47,48], with the fraction of VO4 increasing with the Mg/V molar ratio (for details see Supplementary Information). The formation of the well-ordered Mg2V2O7 was observed only in the MgVOx/Al(4.0) sample. At the same time, the Mg2V2O7 formation is unexpected for this Mg/V molar ratio. The formation of Mg2V2O7 instead of Mg3V2O8 is connected with the strong interaction between the monolayer two-dimensional VOx species and the support in the VOx/Al sample favoring the formation of the two-dimensional phases in the MgVOx/Al samples. Thereby, the detailed characterization of the dispersed phases in VOx/Al and MgVOx/Al samples by the UV-vis DR and Raman spectroscopies confirms the primary formation of surface two-dimensional monolayer VOx and MgVOx species with different coordination and local environment of V(V) depending on the Mg content. The changes in the composition and structure of the surface vanadia species with the increase in the Mg/V molar ratio at a constant vanadia surface density is consistent with the previously obtained results for MgO-modified supported vanadia catalysts [27]. However, in the present work, the primarily formation of the two-dimensional surface species is observed, while the formation of the well-ordered Mg2V2O7 is observed only for the large excess of modifier (Mg/V ratio of 4.0). At the same time, for the previously studied series of the MgVOx/Al2O3 samples prepared using ammonium metavanadate as a vanadia precursor, the formation of microcrystalline magnesium vanadates is already observed at the Mg/V ratio of 0.89–1.51. This could be caused by a lower degree of aggregation of vanadia species in the samples (vanadia surface density corresponded to ∼0.5 monolayer) as well as the presence of some microcrystalline V2O5 phase affecting the interaction of the supported components during the sample preparation. 3.4 Temperature-programmed reduction The reducibility of the vanadia species formed in the samples was studied by the TPR-H2. Fig. 5 a shows the TPR-H2 profiles of the V-containing samples, and Table 3 represents the profile parameters. No hydrogen consumption was observed for the alumina support (the profile is not presented for brevity). All V-containing samples are characterized by a single peak of hydrogen consumption in the TPR-H2 profile. The profile of the unmodified VOx/Al sample is characterized by the peak in the range of 325–760 °C with a peak maximum at 513 °C attributed to the V(V) reduction to V(III) in the polymeric surface VOx species [49]. The peak area corresponds to the consumption of 1.24 mmol H2/g. The amount of hydrogen consumed is less than the theoretical amount for the reduction of V5+ to V3+ in the sample, with the degree of reduction being 72%. This indicates that a part of vanadium exists as V(IV) and/or V(III), which is consistent with the UV-vis DR data indicating the presence of V(IV) in the VOx/Al sample. The modification of the sample with MgO results in a gradual shift of the reduction peak towards higher temperatures as the Mg/V ratio increases, which is accompanied by the increase of the degree of V(V) reduction to V(III) (Table 3). This indirectly indicates the increase of the V–O bond strength in the surface VOx species with the increase of the Mg/V ratio additionally confirmed by the activation energy ETPR-H2 of the hydrogen interaction with the surface oxygen determined from the TPR-H2 data. However, there is no linear correlation between the activation energy ETPR-H2 and Mg/V molar ratio (Fig. 5b, black line, R2 = 0.51). The change of the V–O bond strength with the increase of the Mg/V ratio is rather exponential and characterized by a sharp increase with the Mg/V ratio increase to up to 0.8 followed by a moderate growth at the subsequent increase of the Mg/V ratio (Fig. 5b, red curve described by the equation ETPR-H2=exp(5.258-0.338/(Mg/V + 0.495), R2 = 0.93). This indicates that not only does the binding energy of V–O bonds depend on the amount of magnesium incorporated into the surface VOx species, but also on the structural features (vanadium coordination and local environment) of the surface MgVOx species formed. To further analyze the changes in the V–O bond strength with the structural features of the surface vanadia species, the number of covalent V–O–V bonds in the coordination sphere of the central V(V) cation (CVB) was calculated based on the UV-vis spectroscopy data using the equation CVB = (14.03-3.95·Eg) (±0.34) proposed for vanadia species by Gao and Wachs [35]. As indicated above (see section 3.2), the CVB number for the supported samples with a monolayer vanadia surface density represents the packing density of vanadia polyhedrons depending on coordination and nature of ligands in the second coordination sphere of the central V(V) cation and indicating the changing in the structure of the surface MgVOx species with the increase of the Mg/V ratio. Fig. 5c shows a scatter plot for the activation energy ETPR-H2 and the CVB number. According to this plot, a correlation between the V–O bond strength and the CVB number is rather good (R2 = 0.84) as compared with that between the V–O bond strength and the Mg/V molar ratio. Taking into account the determination accuracy of CVB (±0.34), the correlation can be improved. Correction of CVB numbers by ±0.34 for the samples with Mg/V ratio of 0.8, 1.1, 1.7 and 4.0 significantly improves the correlation (R2 = 0.95). All this confirms the change in V–O bond strength with the change in the structure of monolayer surface vanadia species due to Mg incorporation resulting in variation of vanadium coordination (VO4, VO5/VO6) and the way of connection of vanadia polyhedra. 3.5 TPD-NH3 and pulsed NH3 adsorption The surface acid properties of the samples were studied by TPD-NH3 and pulse NH3 adsorption. Fig. 6 a shows the TPD-NH3 profiles for the support and catalysts. All samples are characterized by the NH3 desorption in the range of 100–450 °C, with two desorption peaks being distinguished at ∼175 °C and ∼315 °C. The NH3 desorption peak at ∼180 °C can be attributed primarily to the weak Bronsted acid sites, while the peak at ∼310 °C can be attributed to the strong Bronsted and Lewis acid sites [50,51]. The total amount of the acid sites on the surface as well as the amount of strong acid sites were determined by pulse NH3 adsorption at 100 °C and 250 °C, respectively (Fig. 6b). The alumina support is characterized by the low surface concentration of the acid sites (0.32 μmol/m2). The considerable increase of the total concentration of acid sites up to 3.05 μmol/m2 is observed for the VOx/Al sample due to the formation of the surface vanadia species. The subsequent modification of the VOx/Al sample with MgO results in a gradual decrease of the total concentration of the acid sites in MgVOx(0.4), MgVOx(0.8), MgVOx(1.1), MgVOx(1.7) as the Mg/V molar ratio increases, with the amount of strong acid sites symbasically decreasing. Further increase of the MgO content does not strongly affect the total surface concentration of the acid sites. 3.6 Catalytic characteristics and their relationships with the composition and structure of vanadia surface species, the reducibility and surface acidity of the catalysts Fig. 7 shows the catalytic performance of the samples in the propane ODH at 500 °C. The VOx/Al sample is characterized by high propane conversion, but low selectivity to propene (<45% even at low conversion). The sample modification with MgO results in a gradual decrease of the propane conversion as the Mg/V molar ratio increases, with the propane conversion for the MgVOx/Al(1.1) and MgVOx/Al(1.7) samples being close. According to the intrinsic reaction rate of propane transformation over the samples, the conversion decrease is caused by changing of the catalytic activity of the MgO-modified samples (Table 4 ), but not by the decrease of their specific surface area. This is additionally confirmed by the increase of the apparent activation energy of the propane transformation with an increase of the Mg/V molar ratio. The significant changes in the sample activity are observed at the Mg/V ratio up to 0.8, while the activity changes are less pronounced at a further increase of the Mg/V ratio. The decrease of the sample activity is accompanied by the increase of the selectivity towards propylene in comparison with the unmodified VOx/Al sample, with the degree of the selectivity increase depending on the Mg/V molar ratio. The increase of the Mg/V ratio to up to 0.8 results in the notable selectivity increase, but a further increase of the Mg/V ratio results in an oscillation of the selectivity within the limits of 14%. Similar dependencies were observed earlier for the limited series of samples with a lower vanadia surface density obtained using ammonium metavanadate as a vanadia precursor [27] (see the comparison of the samples in Supplementary Information). Thereby, the modification of the monolayer VOx/Al catalyst with MgO accompanied by the changes in the composition and structure of the surface vanadia species leads to the noticeable changes in the catalytic performances of the MgVOx/Al samples. To clarify the key factors affecting the catalyst properties, the correlations between the catalytic characteristics and the reducibility and surface acidity of the catalysts were analyzed. Fig. 8 shows scatter plots for the activation energies ETPR-H2 and Ea as well as for the ETPR-H2 and the w2/w1 rate ratio. The activation energies ETPR-H2, Ea, and the w2/w1 rate ratio characterize the binding energy of V–O bonds in the surface vanadia phases, the catalytic activity, and the catalyst selectivity towards propylene, respectively. According to this plot, the increase of the V–O bond strength correlates well with the decrease in the catalytic activity of the samples (R2 = 0.93). Similar correlation is rather typical for oxidative reactions [7,52]. However, according to the scatter plot for the w2/w1 ratio and the activation energy ETPR-H2, the correlation between the V–O bond strength and the selectivity that nonmonotonically depends on the Mg/V molar ratio (Table 4) is rather poor (R2 = 0.79). Thus, it can be concluded that the presence of weakly bound oxygen in vanadia species leads to a high rate of hydrocarbon conversion, but also significantly reduces the selectivity due to the rapid oxidation of the more reactive propylene formed. The increased binding energy of V–O bonds due to Mg doping inhibited the lattice oxygen evolution for propane overoxidation. At the same time, the increase in the V–O bond strength in vanadia species is not the only factor providing high selectivity towards propylene. Fig. 9 shows a scatter plot for the w2/w1 ratio and the surface concentration of the acid sites in the catalyst. The analysis of the correlation between the surface acidity and the selectivity towards propylene shows that there is a rather good correlation for the surface concentration of strong acid sites (R2 = 0.86), but not for the total surface concentration of the acid centers (R2 = 0.69). This is consistent with the fact that under the reaction conditions (450–500 °C), the catalyst surface is dehydrated and is characterized by the presence of predominantly strong Lewis sites. However, there is a notable scattering of the selectivity values in the scatter plots for the w2/w1 rate ratio and the surface concentration of acid sites for the samples characterized by a low surface concentration of the acid sites (<0.5 μmol/m2). The high surface acidity of the VOx/Al sample seems to result in strong propylene adsorption accompanied by the formation of the surface carboxylate species. This is consistent with the in-situ DRIFT studies of propane and propylene adsorption on the supported vanadia catalysts [53]. The sample modification with MgO results in a drastic elimination of the acid sites in the MgVOx/Al samples that can facilitate the propylene desorption. Similar result was obtained for the undoped and K-doped VOx/Al2O3 catalysts [19]. The experiments on pulsed propylene adsorption additionally confirm that the high surface acidity of the VOx/Al sample leads to its strong adsorption accompanied by the CO2 release, while only a small part of propylene irreversibly adsorbed over the MgVOx/Al(0.8) sample characterized by lower acidity (Fig. 10 ). The deviation from the correlation observed for MgVOx/Al(1.1) and MgVOx/Al(4.0) samples can be attributed to the effect of the surface species structure on the propylene adsorption. Indeed, given the high reaction temperatures causing the sample dehydration, the surface vanadia species in the VOx/Al, MgVOx/Al(0.4), MgVOx/Al(0.8), and MgVOx/Al(1.7) samples seem to be primarily formed by VO4 polyhedra combined in polymer structures, while those in the MgVOx/Al(1.1) sample are primarily formed by the VO5 polyhedra combined with the VO4 polyhedra in the polymer structures. The species in the MgVOx/Al(4.0) sample are formed by the V2O7 dimers of corner-sharing tetrahedrons. The latter structures seem to contribute to stronger propylene adsorption to form surface carboxylate structures. The exclusion of points for MgVOx/Al(1.1) and MgVOx/Al(4.0) samples significantly improve both correlations in Fig. 9 (R2 = 0.88 for total concentration and R2 = 0.98 for the concentration of strong acid sites) confirming the suggestion. Thus, it is the Mg incorporation into the structure of the surface vanadia species that determine the surface species structure, binding energy of V–O bonds, and surface acidity. The changes in these characteristics are directly determined by the Mg/V molar ratio at a given vanadia surface density. To determine the best Mg/V ratio for the monolayer MgVOx/Al samples providing the best combination of these factors, the change in the propylene yield with a change in the Mg/V ratio at a given propane conversion (∼6%) is considered (Fig. 11 ). The sample with the Mg/V ratio of 4.0 was not taken into account since the propane conversion of ∼6% was not achieved in the study due to the low activity of the sample. According to this data, the sample with the Mg/V molar ratio of 0.8 shows the highest yield of propylene. The samples with the Mg/V molar ratios of 1.1 and 1.7 also show relatively high propylene yield but are characterized by lower activity. 4 Conclusions The detail characterization of the VOx/Al and MgVOx/Al samples by UV-vis DR spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy confirms the primarily formation of the surface two-dimensional monolayer VOx and MgVOx species on the surface of the alumina support with different coordination and the local environment of V(V) depending on the Mg content. The Mg incorporation into the structure of the surface vanadia species affects both their redox and acid properties and allows controlling the catalyst activity and selectivity towards propylene. The changes in the catalytic activity of the MgVOx/Al2O3 samples are affected by changes in the binding energy of V–O bonds in the 2D vanadia species due to the Mg incorporation into the second coordination sphere of V. The presence of the weakly bound oxygen in the vanadia species leads to a high rate of hydrocarbon conversion but also significantly reduces the selectivity due to the rapid oxidation of the more reactive propylene formed. The increased binding energy of V–O bonds due to Mg doping inhibited the lattice oxygen evolution for propane overoxidation, but is not the only factor determining high selectivity towards propylene. The selectivity of the monolayer MgVOx/Al2O3 catalyst is shown to be also affected by both the surface concentration of strong acid sites and the structure of the surface species. The high surface acidity of the samples is assumed to provide strong propylene adsorption accompanied by the formation of the surface carboxylate species. For the samples characterized by a low concentration of acid sites (<0.5 μmol/m2), the surface species structure is a defining factor for propylene adsorption and further transformations. These new insights into the structure and chemistry of the monolayer MgVOx/Al2O3 catalyst provide the basis for the rational design of advanced catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of light hydrocarbons. coredata.dc:description: Here we report the relationships between the structure of the vanadia species, acid-base, and redox properties of the surface of tailor-made monolayer MgVOx/Al2O3 catalysts and the effects of these features on the performance of such catalysts. Combined Raman and UV-vis DR spectroscopies confirmed the formation of the alumina-supported 2D surface VOx and MgVOx species with different coordination and local environment of the active site. The Mg incorporation into the structure of the surface vanadia species was shown to affect both their redox and acid properties and allows controlling the catalyst activity and selectivity towards propylene. Increasing the binding energy of V–O bonds due to Mg doping was shown to be critical to improve the catalyst performance but is not the only factor determining high selectivity towards propylene that is also affected by the concentration of strong acid sites and surface species structure.
coredata.dc:title: Monolayer MgVOx/Al2O3 catalysts for propane oxidative dehydrogenation: Insights into a role of structural, redox, and acid-base properties in catalytic performance
